docs.snippet: A motorcyclist from hell treads the red carpet....
docs.lead_paragraph: Eva Mendes, who appears in "Ghost Rider," upstaged the star of the film, Nicolas Cage, at the New York premiere Thursday night in Times Square. The movie is based on the Marvel Comics character Johnny Blaze, a motorcyclist who has given up his soul to the devil (don't ask) and pursues demons who have been cast out of hell (don't ask).
docs.abstract: A motorcyclist from hell treads the red carpet.

docs.snippet: The man behind the man in the "Half Nelson" campaign....
docs.lead_paragraph: Reuters points out that many of the contenders for best actor played bad guys, including a dictator, a mercenary and a crackhead. Ryan Gosling, who played a teacher mixed up with a white, chalky substance, told Reuters he did his research. "I smoke a lot of crack," he said. Such a kidder,that guy.
docs.abstract: The man behind the man in the "Half Nelson" campaign.

headline.print_headline: In Foreign Oscar Entries, the Past Masks the Present

docs.snippet: Sesame Street, that cheeriest of addresses, is now singing the blues. But young fans don't have to worry that their favorite haunt has become melancholy; it's also singing the reds, the yellows and every other shade that the primary hues create. '...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sesame Street, that cheeriest of addresses, is now singing the blues. But young fans don't have to worry that their favorite haunt has become melancholy; it's also singing the reds, the yellows and every other shade that the primary hues create. ''Elmo's Coloring Book,'' a production of Sesame Street Live, celebrates the entire spectrum with music, movement, humor and spectacle. The 90-minute show, in revival at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, stars Professor Art, a pleasant variation on a mad inventor. His singing and dancing sidekicks are the Palettes (the accent is on the second syllable), a trio of furry monsters who are supposed to be like the Rockettes, except they obviously don't shave their legs. Professor Art has created the Guzzinta 2000, a machine that takes the characters inside the coloring book of that little red monster, Elmo, above. First stop is ancient Egypt, which you might say is brought to you by the letter T: Telly plays King Tut, who collects treasure and loves triangles. Then it's on to a prehistoric scene, in which Bert and Ernie meet a boogieing blue dinosaur. In the midst of this merrymaking, the book's colors start to disappear. The situation becomes critical when Oscar the Grouch turns snow white and starts singing the praises of puppies and rainbows. A world without a grumpy Oscar is just, well, colorless. The audience helps solve the mystery while enjoying numbers like ''Red-Hot Tango'' and Cookie Monster's ''Fuzzy and Blue'' (to the tune of ''It Had to Be You''). A children's show about color usually also has something to say about the diversity of people. ''Elmo's Coloring Book'' does it gently, emphasizing friendship. Or, as one song puts it, ''It takes all of us to make a rainbow.'' (Today at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m., tomorrow and Sunday at 10:30 a.m., 2 p.m. and 5:30 p.m.; Monday at 10:30 a.m. and 2 p.m.; 212-465-6741. Tickets: $15, $26, $37 and $54. ) LAUREL GRAEBER

headline.main: SPARE TIMES: Feb. 16 - Feb. 22; 'ELMO'S COLORING BOOK'

docs.snippet: SEVEN YEARS AND COUNTING -- For seven years, Martin A. Armstrong, a onetime globe-trotting investment manager, has been in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Lower Manhattan for contempt of court. Imprisoned two years before Enron and WorldCo...
docs.lead_paragraph: SEVEN YEARS AND COUNTING -- For seven years, Martin A. Armstrong, a onetime globe-trotting investment manager, has been in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Lower Manhattan for contempt of court. Imprisoned two years before Enron and WorldCom brought corporate crime to center stage, Mr. Armstrong, 57, is the white-collar defendant whom time forgot. [Page A1.] TIVO WATCHERS WATCH ADS -- People with digital video recorders like TiVo never watch commercials, right? Wrong. According to new data, people who own digital video reporters still watch about two-thirds of the ads. [A1.] FIRM ORDERED TO PAY $160 MILLION -- A federal judge ordered Bear Stearns to pay nearly $160 million to investors in a hedge fund for failing to properly monitor the activities of the fund before it collapsed. [C1.] AMERICAN TO LEAD CREDIT SUISSE -- Brady Dougan, a Midwesterner, has been named chief executive of Credit Suisse group, a major global bank and one that has never had an American -- or a non-German speaker, for that matter -- as its sole chief executive. [C1.] SCALING BACK EXPECTATIONS -- Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, told Wall Street analysts that some of them are being too optimistic about sales of Windows Vista, the latest version of the Windows operating system. Mr. Ballmer, above, said forecasts for sales in the fiscal year beginning in July were too high, noting that the analysts' spreadsheet models called for slower growth in the personal computer industry. [C4.] MICROSOFT'S INSIGNIFICANT LOSS -- A Russian judge convicted a provincial school headmaster of using pirated Microsoft software in school computers, but declined to impose any penalty, saying that Microsoft's loss was insignificant compared with its overall earnings. [C6.] HOME PRICES FELL IN LATE 2006 -- Prices for single-family homes fell in more than half of the nation's 149 biggest metropolitan areas in the last three months of 2006, according to data from a trade group for real estate agents. [C1.] A BILL TO REGULATE TOBACCO -- A bipartisan group of congressmen reintroduced legislation that would allow the federal government to regulate the tobacco industry by cracking down on marketing aimed at young people. [C1.] BERNANKE SEES STRENGTH -- The Federal Reserve would raise interest rates if inflation moved higher, the Fed's chairman, Ben S. Bernanke said, noting that the economy might be stronger than it appears. [C2.] FEWER NEW CUSTOMERS -- Vonage Holdings, the Internet phone company, lost less money last quarter, but it gained fewer new customers, indicating that competition may be intensifying. The company said that it added 166,000 new subscriber lines in the fourth quarter, down from about 204,600 in the third quarter -- the first sign of slowing subscriber growth since the company went public last spring. [C4.] ABC'S OSCAR SHOW IS BOOKED -- ABC has already sold all the commercials it plans to run during the Feb. 25 broadcast of the 79th annual Academy Awards ceremony. The sold-out sign went up a bit earlier than last year, despite slightly higher prices. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C3.] JOB CHANGES AT NBC UNIVERSAL -- Jeff Zucker, newly installed as the chief executive of NBC Universal, announced a series of executive promotions involving three longtime NBC executives [C6.] STEADY RATES IN JAPAN -- Japan's surprisingly strong growth in the last quarter of 2006 was just a one-time surge by an otherwise sluggish economy and is not likely to push the central bank to raise interest rates next week, economists in Tokyo said. [C6.] NEW INQUIRY INTO DRILLING FEES -- Top Democrats on the Senate Energy Committee ordered a new inquiry into the Interior Department's program to collect billions of dollars worth of oil and gas from companies that drill on public territory. [C3.] NORTHWEST SETS NET WORTH -- Northwest Airlines said that it expected to be worth about $7 billion when it emerged from bankruptcy later this year and that it would pay unsecured creditors roughly three-quarters of what they were owed. [C7.] WARNING ON PEANUT BUTTER -- ConAgra Foods told consumers to discard certain jars of Peter Pan and Great Value peanut butter after a salmonella outbreak sickened almost 300 people. [A19.] GIFTS TO GOVERNOR QUESTIONED -- Federal authorities are investigating gifts and payments that Gov. Jim Gibbons of Nevada received when he was a member of Congress from an executive of a software company that received millions in dollars of federal contracts, government officials said. [A20.] DELAY IN PORT DEAL -- The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has caused a political uproar by seeking to delay a deal by A.I.G. Global Investment Group, an arm of the American insurance giant, to buy rights to run port terminals from DP World, the port operator owned by the Maktoum royal family of Dubai. [B2.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. The Molson Coors Brewing Company, one of the world's biggest beer companies, said that its fourth-quarter profit soared on increased sales volume, a lower tax rate and cost savings. (AP) Biogen Idec reported that its fourth-quarter profit nearly doubled on growing sales of treatments for cancer and multiple sclerosis. But the company's profit and revenue both fell short of Wall Street expectations, and shares fell sharply. (AP) Lawyers for Conrad M. Black, former head of the Hollinger media empire, asked a judge to bar prosecutors from showing jurors a tape on which a shareholder calls the him ''a thief.'' (AP)

docs.snippet: Around Town    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. Through Aug. 19, ''Gold,'' with coins, jewelry and other artifacts. Through Sunday, ''Yellowstone to Yukon,'' an exhibition of more than 40 ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Around Town Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. Through Aug. 19, ''Gold,'' with coins, jewelry and other artifacts. Through Sunday, ''Yellowstone to Yukon,'' an exhibition of more than 40 photographs by 11 photographers documenting the animals, vegetation and geology of the regions affected by one of the world's largest wildlife conservation initiatives. Through May 28, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' a display with hundreds of butterflies in a re-creation of their natural habitat. In the Imax theater, ''Roving Mars,'' a film about NASA's Mars Rover. Timed tickets to ''Gold'' and ''The Butterfly Conservatory,'' which include museum admission, are $21; $16 for students and 60+; $12 for 12 and younger. Imax tickets, which include museum admission, are $21; $16 for students and 60+; $12 for children under 12. Suggested museum admission: $14; $10.50 for students and 60+; children, $8. Combination tickets, including museum and Rose Center admission and the Hayden Planetarium space show (''Cosmic Collisions''): $22; $16.50 for students and 60+; $13 for 12 and younger; under 2, free. Admission that includes all activities: $30; $23 for students and 60+; $19 for 12 and younger. The Rose Center is open until 8:45 p.m. for ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' with jazz, a cash bar and tapas, on the first Friday of every month. Museum hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. (to 8:45 p.m. on Fridays). (212) 769-5100 or (212) 769-5200; amnh.org. HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmond Town. Tomorrow at 7:30 and 9 p.m., the Tavern Concert season continues with ''Songs of the Sea and Taverns''; $15. Through April 1, ''Out of Fire and Valor: Staten Island War Memorials,'' photographs by Cal Snyder, a Marine Corps veteran. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. $5; $4 for 62+; $3.50 for students and 5 to 17; free for children under 5 and members; (718) 351-1611. MOUNT VERNON HOTEL MUSEUM AND GARDEN, 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan. Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''George Washington's Birthday Ball,'' with traditional dances, music and refreshments; $10; $8 for members; $5 for children under 12. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission: $8; students and 62+, $7; under 12, free. (212) 838-6878. MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. Through Monday, ''Black Style Now.'' Tomorrow at 3 p.m., a sword-dance performance in celebration of the 22nd New York Sword Dance Festival. Sunday at 3 p.m., ''Blues Culture and the Roots of Hip Hop,'' a lecture by Jelani Cobb, author of ''To the Break of Dawn: A Freestyle on the Hip Hop Aesthetic.'' Wednesday at 6:30 p.m., ''Saul Steinberg's New York: A Conversation with Ian Frazier and Joel Smith,'' a discussion of the images of New York City created by Steinberg for The New Yorker, with Mr. Frazier, a staff writer at the magazine, and Mr. Smith, a curator and scholar; $9; $5 for members; reservations required: (212) 534-1672, Ext. 3395. Through May 28, ''Robert Moses and the Modern City: Remaking the Metropolis,'' one of three exhibitions dedicated to Moses at cultural institutions in the city; the others are at the Queens Museum of Art and the Wallach Art Gallery at Columbia University. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; open this Monday for Presidents' Day. Suggested admission: $9; $5 for students and 62+; free for children under 12; $20 for families; free on Sundays, 10 a.m. to noon. (212) 534-1672, mcny.org. MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 36-01 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Sunday at 2 p.m., Ron van Clief, an actor and martial arts expert will discuss his careers in both fields. Screenings this weekend: tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''The Power of Nightmares: The Rise of the Politics of Fear'' (2004), directed by Adam Curtis; at 6:30 p.m., ''F for Fake'' (1974), directed by Orson Welles. Sunday at 5 p.m., a preview of ''Lake of Fire,'' a 2006 documentary about abortion by Tony Kaye that will be commercially released in October at Film Forum. Monday through Friday at 1:30 p.m., screenings of ''Happy Feet'' (2006), preceded by a workshop for children 6 and older on the techniques used to create the dancing penguins. Through April 15, ''Star Trek: 40 Years of Fandom,'' an exhibition of figures, games, comic books and magazines, and fan-produced films. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, noon to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6:30 p.m.; and by appointment; open this Monday and Tuesday, noon to 5 p.m. Films and videos, unless noted, are free with admission: $10; ages 65+ and students, $7.50; 5 to 18, $5; free for members and children 4 and younger; free for everyone on Fridays from 4 to 8 p.m. Friday night screenings require admission. (718) 784-0077, movingimage.us. Events NATIONAL WOMAN'S HEART DAY HEALTH FAIR, Madison Square Garden. Today, 7:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m., with free health screenings, massages and raffles. Sponsored by Sister to Sister: Everyone Has a Heart Foundation. womansheartday.org. ANNUAL NEW YORK SWORD DANCE FESTIVAL, with folk music and dancing. Tomorrow at 9:30 a.m. and Sunday at 12:30 p.m. at various locations in Manhattan and Brooklyn, including the Port Authority Bus Terminal, the Donnell Library Center, the Park Slope Methodist Church and the Museum of the City of New York. Admission fees depend on the location. Schedule: halfmoonsword.org. MEET THE OSCARS, Times Square Studios, 1500 Broadway, at 44th Street. Through Feb. 24, an exhibition of Oscar statues that includes those given to Clark Gable for ''It Happened One Night'' (1934) and to Bette Davis for ''Jezebel'' (1938). Fifty other statues that haven't yet been awarded can also be seen, and visitors will be allowed to hold one of the unawarded Oscars. Daily, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Free. oscars.org. 32ND ANNUAL THUNDERBIRD AMERICAN INDIAN DANCERS CONCERT AND POW-WOW, Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m., music, dancing and storytelling. $10; $1 for children under 12 with an adult at matinee performances. (212) 254-1109; theaterforthenewcity.net. CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK GRADUATE CENTER, 365 Fifth Avenue, at 34th Street. Tonight at 7, a screening of ''Soy Andina,'' a documentary about Peruvian dance directed by Mitch Teplitsky, followed by a performance by subjects of the film; $15; (212) 817-8215. Wednesday at 6:15 p.m., ''The Jews of Albania,'' a lecture by Sami Repishti, an author and teacher; free; (212) 817-1949. Thursday at 1 p.m., a performance of chamber music by musicians in the doctoral music program; free; (212) 817-8607. Thursday at 6:30 p.m.; ''Double Agents: An Evening with Contemporary Russian Artists,'' a discussion with writers and artists born in the former Soviet Union; free; (212) 817-2005. CITY RELIQUARY MUSEUM, 370 Metropolitan Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Thursday night at 7:30, ''A Night of Poetry, Music and Libations''; $5 donation. cityreliquary.org. TOLERANCE AND DIVERSITY EXHIBITIONS, New York Tolerance Center, 226 East 42nd Street, Manhattan. Monday at noon and 3 p.m., guided, interactive tours of exhibitions that challenge views of diversity and tolerance. The center, which offers diversity training for educational and law enforcement groups, is usually open only to groups and not individuals. $20; $15, children 12 and older and 65+. Reservations required: (212) 697-1180. QUIET DAY SERIES: SPA FOR THE SOUL, Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., workshops in methods of peaceful contemplation and how those used by 14th-century mystics, Jesuits, early Anglicans and others can be adapted for use today. $10, including lunch. Registration: (212) 602-0807. 'WINTER WEDNESDAYS: A CENTURY OF FILM ON THE LOWER EAST SIDE,' Center for Jewish History, 15 West 16th Street, Flatiron district. This Wednesday night at 7, a screening of ''Crossing Delancey'' (1988), directed by Joan Micklin Silver, followed by a discussion led by Beth Wenger, a history professor at the University of Pennsylvania. $10; $5 for members. (917) 606-8200. 'TALES FROM THE CRYPT,' Fort Greene Park, Myrtle Avenue and Washington Park, Brooklyn. Tomorrow at 1 p.m., a tour of the park and a discussion of the Prison Ship Martyrs Monument, now under renovation, that contains a vault with remains of Americans held as prisoners of war during the Revolutionary War, meeting at the Visitors Center. Sponsored by the Urban Park Rangers. Information: 311. BROOKLYN PUBLIC LIBRARY, Grand Army Plaza at Flatbush Avenue and Eastern Parkway. Black History Month events. Tomorrow: at 1 p.m., a performance of dance and drumming; at 2 p.m., a screening of the documentary ''All on a Mardi Gras Day'' by Royce Osborn; at 4 p.m., a celebration of African-American culture at the turn of the century with a reading of Patricia McKissack's ''Mirandy and Brother Wind'' and a performance of Scott Joplin's ragtime music. (718) 230-2100. WATSON ADVENTURES Tonight at 6 and tomorrow at 4:30 p.m., ''The Murder at the Met Scavenger Hunt,'' a search for a curator's murderer through the Metropolitan Museum of Art. $39, including museum admission. Meeting place and reservations: (877) 946-4868. Spoken Word 'SLAVERY IN NEW YORK,' Hudson Guild, 441 West 26th Street, Chelsea. Thursday at 6 p.m., a lecture on slavery during colonial times, by Elizabeth Grant, a staff member of the New-York Historical Society. Free. (212) 760-9800. Walking Tours MUNICIPAL ART SOCIETY Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''New York in the Time of George Washington,'' a historical walk in Lower Manhattan, meeting on the southeast corner of Broadway and Chambers Street. $15 , $12 for members. (212) 935-3960. DR. PHIL: NEW YORK WALKS AND TALKS Sunday at 1:30 p.m., ''George Washington and Slavery in New York,'' a Lower Manhattan walk that combines a historical look at slavery in the city during Washington's days as general and president. Monday at 11 a.m., ''Presidential Ghosts,'' a Lower Manhattan tour of sites associated with George Washington, Aaron Burr, Edgar Allan Poe and Alexander Hamilton. Both meet inside Blimpies Restaurant, 38 Park Row, between Spruce and Beekman Streets, Lower Manhattan. $15. (718) 591-4741. BIG ONION WALKING TOURS Today at 1 p.m., ''Celebrate Black History Month'' with a walk through historic Harlem, meeting on the northwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 135th Street. Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''Historic Chinatown-Celebrate the Year of the Pig,'' meeting on the southeast corner of Grand and Chrystie Streets. Monday at 1 p.m., ''Revolutionary New York'' covers Lower Manhattan sites associated with George Washington and the Revolutionary War, meeting at Broadway and Murray Street. $15 each; $12 for 63+; $10 for students and New-York Historical Society members. (212) 439-1090; bigonion.com. SHOREWALKERS Tomorrow at 10 a.m., ''Edge of Bronx 1: University Heights to Crotona Park,'' meeting at the 207th Street subway stop on the No. 1 train. $3. (212) 666-4553. 'CHINATOWN NEW YEAR: YEAR OF THE BOAR,' Sunday at 1 p.m., will focus on the history, culture and landmarks of the neighborhood, meeting on the northwest corner of Canal and Centre Streets. Sponsored by I'll Take Manhattan Tours. $15. (732) 270-5559. GREENWICH VILLAGE LITERARY PUB CRAWL, tomorrow at 2 p.m., with actors leading a tour of bars and landmarks with a rich literary history, meeting at the White Horse Tavern, 567 Hudson Street, at 11th Street, West Village. Sponsored by Bakerloo Theater Project. $15; $12 for students and 60+, not including drinks or food. Reservations: (212) 613-5796. WALKING AND TASTING TOUR OF CHINATOWN, today and tomorrow at 1 p.m. Sponsored by NYC Chinatown Tours. $35, including food. Reservations and meeting place: (646) 713-9960. METRO TOUR SERVICE Mondays at 2 p.m. in February, a tour focusing on the African-American cultural presence in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant, meeting on the corner of Lafayette Avenue and Hanson Place in Fort Greene. Today and tomorrow at 2 p.m., Brooklyn Heights, Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. Sunday at 3 p.m., a gospel tour. These tours meet in front of the Marriott Hotel, Adams and Tillary Streets, downtown Brooklyn. Each, $25. (718) 789-0430. Recreation NYRR THURSDAY NIGHT AT THE RACES 2007, New Balance Track and Field Center at the Armory, 216 Fort Washington Avenue, at 168th Street, Washington Heights. Thursday at 7 p.m., indoor races ranging from 800 meters to 2 miles. $10. Registration begins at 6:15 p.m. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners. (212) 860-4455; nyrrc.org.

docs.snippet: Opens today nationwide.  Not rated; 137 minutes       The five live-action films in this anthology of Oscar-nominated shorts tend toward sentiment and slickness. ''The Saviour,'' an Australian production about a Mormon missionary in love with a ma...
docs.lead_paragraph: Opens today nationwide. Not rated; 137 minutes The five live-action films in this anthology of Oscar-nominated shorts tend toward sentiment and slickness. ''The Saviour,'' an Australian production about a Mormon missionary in love with a married woman, is charming but cutesy. ''West Bank Story,'' an American musical spoof in which Arabs and Jews make like Sharks and Jets, is lavishly produced but trite.
docs.abstract: Matt Zoller Seitz reviews The 2006 Academy Award-Nominated Short Films, which includes both live-action and animated shorts; photo (M)
